journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Isolation and Characterization of Human Mesenchymal Stem Cells Derived From Shoulder Tissues Involved in Rotator Cuff Tears

article-meta.aff: †Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, School of Medicine, University of Occupational and Environmental Health, Kitakyushu, Japan
‡Department of Cartilage Regeneration, Tokyo Medical and Dental University, Tokyo, Japan
Investigation performed at the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, School of Medicine, University of Occupational and Environmental Health, Kitakyushu, Japan

author-notes.corresp: *Hajime Utsunomiya, MD, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, School of Medicine, University of Occupational and Environmental Health, 1-1 Iseigaoka, Yahatanishi-ku, Kitakyushu 807-8555, Japan (e-mail: utsu@med.uoeh-u.ac.jp).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Recent studies report a relatively high failure rate for tendon-bone healing after rotator cuff repair. Several studies have investigated biologically augmented rotator cuff repair; however, none has shown the application of synovial mesenchymal stem cells for such repair.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: To demonstrate whether cells derived from shoulder tissues have mesenchymal stem cell properties and to identify which tissue is the best source of the mesenchymal stem cells.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Controlled laboratory study.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Forty-two patients with a diagnosed rotator cuff tear preoperatively were enrolled in this study. Human mesenchymal tissues were obtained during arthroscopic surgery for rotator cuff tears from 19 donors who met the inclusion criteria and had investigable amounts of tissue. Colony-forming units, yield obtained, expandability, differentiation potential, epitope profile, and gene expression were compared among the cells from 4 shoulder tissues: synovium of the glenohumeral joint, subacromial bursa, margin of the ruptured supraspinatus tendon, and residual tendon stump on the greater tuberosity (enthesis).

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The number of live passage 0 cells from whole tissue was significantly higher in cells derived from the subacromial bursa (P < .05). Subacromial bursa–derived cells retained their expandability even at passage 10. In adipogenesis experiments, the frequency of Oil Red O–positive colonies was significantly higher for synovium- and subacromial bursa–derived cells than for tendon- and enthesis-derived cells (P < .0001). In studies of osteogenesis, the rate of von Kossa– and alkaline phosphatase–positive colonies was highest in subacromial bursa–derived cells (P < .0001). The chondrogenic potential was highest in cells derived from the enthesis. For epitope profiling, 11 surface antigens were measured, and most had similar epitope profiles, irrespective of cell source.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: The findings indicate that the subacromial bursa is a good candidate for the source of mesenchymal stem cells in rotator cuff tears.

sec.title: Clinical Relevance:
sec.p: Synovial cells from the subacromial bursa in patients with rotator cuff tears are a superior cell source in vitro, suggesting that mesenchymal stem cells from this tissue could be good candidates for biological augmentation of rotator cuff repair.

body.p: A rotator cuff tear is a common cause of shoulder pain and dysfunction, especially in older people.52 Although arthroscopic rotator cuff repair has been widely used to obtain good or excellent results,29,49 a relatively higher rate of tendon-bone healing failure has been reported in association with inferior techniques as well as massive tears.7,17 Various biological and pharmacological studies have been reported to suggest methods to improve the rotator cuff healing process after repair. Rodeo et al39 investigated the use of a mixture of osteoinductive growth factors including bone morphogenetic protein (BMP)−2 through 7, transforming growth factor (TGF)−β1 to β3, and fibroblast growth factor (FGF) to improve the healing of the tendon-bone interface in an in vivo sheep model. Seeherman et al42 also demonstrated the role of recombinant human BMP-12 in the repair of rotator cuffs in sheep. Ide et al24 showed that FGF-2 accelerates bone ingrowth at the supraspinatus repair site in a Sprague-Dawley rat model. Bedi et al4 demonstrated that the inhibition of matrix metalloproteinases improves rotator cuff repair in a rat model. Nevertheless, the efficacy of these methods has not been proved clinically.

Mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) have been considered to improve tendon-bone healing. A previous study using a rat anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction model revealed that MSCs derived from knee synovium accelerated early remodeling of tendon-bone healing.26 Nourissat et al34 found that MSC injection for a destroyed enthesis of the Achilles tendon led to organ regenerative healing in terms of an organized enthesis with columnar chondrocytes in a rat model. In contrast, an attempt by Gulotta et al20 to demonstrate that MSCs derived from bone marrow augment healing at rotator cuff repair sites in a rat model yielded no significant differences from the control group.

We therefore isolated MSCs obtained from shoulder intra-articular tissue, including the synovium, and analyzed their expandability and multipotent potential. The purpose of this study was to clarify whether cells derived from shoulder tissues have MSC properties and to identify which tissue would be the best source of MSCs in patients who suffered from rotator cuff tears.

sec.title: Tissue Collection and Isolation of Cells
sec.p: The study was approved by the local institutional review board, and all study participants provided informed consent. Forty-two patients with a rotator cuff tear preoperatively were enrolled in this study. We excluded patients with inflammatory diseases, such as infectious arthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and other systemic collagen diseases. Five patients with a partial rotator cuff tear were also excluded (Figure 1).

caption.p: Inclusion and exclusion chart of this study.

sec.p: Human subacromial bursa, synovium of the glenohumeral joint, margin of a ruptured supraspinatus tendon, and enthesis of the greater tuberosity of the humerus were obtained during arthroscopic rotator cuff repair surgery under general anesthesia. To minimize variation in sampling, specimens were taken from the same anatomic locations. The subacromial bursa near the site of the torn rotator cuff was harvested with a rongeur under arthroscopic observation. The synovium of the glenohumeral joint was obtained from near the anterior labrum by using the same procedure. The margin of the ruptured supraspinatus tendon was carefully harvested only when necessary. We identified an enthesis as the point of the greater tuberosity where the supraspinatus tendon had attached before injury. The enthesis at the greater tuberosity of the humerus was obtained with a rongeur under arthroscopic observation (Figure 2A).

caption.p: Comparison of cells derived from the synovium, subacromial bursa, supraspinatus tendon, and enthesis. (A) Arthroscopic observation and tissue harvesting. (B, C) Histological analysis was performed on tissues stained with (B) hematoxylin and eosin (HE) and (C) toluidine blue from 3 donors (showing 1 representative donor). Only enthesis tissue had a toluidine blue–positive matrix. Bars = 100 μm. (D) Representative cell colonies from 1 donor are shown. Large colonies were observed when the nucleated cells were plated at 103 or 104 cells/dish. If plated at 105 cells/dish, the colonies became indistinct. Bar = 1 cm. (E) Representative morphological features of the cells magnified shown at 14 days (passage 0). The cells from 4 tissues seemed to be similar and of fibroblastic cell morphology. Bar = 200 μm.

sec.p: The subacromial bursa, synovium, supraspinatus tendon, and enthesis of the greater tuberosity samples were digested in 3 mg/mL collagenase from type V (Sigma-Aldrich, St Louis, Missouri) in α-modified Eagle’s medium (α-MEM, Invitrogen, Carlsbad, California) at 37°C. After 2 hours, digested cells were filtered through a 70-μm nylon filter (Becton Dickinson, Franklin Lakes, New Jersey), and the remaining tissue was discarded. The numbers of nucleated cells per milligram of a sample are shown in Table 1. We excluded 12 donors because the number of nucleated cells obtained from each tissue was smaller than 7.0 × 104 (tendon: 9 cases; enthesis: 7 cases; and synovium: 3 cases. The total does not add up because of overlapping) (Figure 1).

caption.p: Data on Cell Samples From 16 Donorsa

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are shown as mean ± standard deviation. Nucleated cells were plated at 104/60 cm2.

fn.label: b
fn.p: P < .05, Steel-Dwass test. Sample weight of the subacromial bursa was significantly higher versus the synovium and enthesis.

fn.label: c
fn.p: P < .05, Steel-Dwass test. Yield obtained of the subacromial bursa was significantly higher versus the enthesis.

sec.p: The digested nucleated cells were plated at 103, 104, and 105 cells per dish (60-cm2 culture dish, Nalge Nunc International, Rochester, New York), with 6 dishes for each cell concentration. Complete culture medium was used (α-MEM containing 10% fetal bovine serum [lot selected for rapid growth of synovial fluid–derived MSCs32], 100 U/mL penicillin, 100 μg/mL streptomycin, and 250 ng/mL amphotericin B [all from Invitrogen]). The cells were incubated at 37°C with 5% humidified CO2. After 3 to 4 days, the medium was changed to remove nonadherent cells, and the adherent cells were then cultured for 14 days as passage 0 without refeeding. Three dishes for each concentration were used for staining with 0.5% crystal violet. The optimal initial cell density was determined by (1) the resultant colony size being unaffected by contact inhibition and (2) a maximum number of colonies being reached (Figure 2D). We then harvested the cells plated at optimal densities from the remaining 3 dishes with Trypsin-EDTA (Invitrogen) and determined the number of cells at passage 0. The passage 0 cells were cryopreserved by resuspension at a concentration of less than 106 cells/mL in α-MEM with 5% dimethyl sulfoxide (Wako, Osaka, Japan) and 20% fetal bovine serum. One-milliliter aliquots were slowly frozen and cryopreserved in liquid nitrogen (passage 0). To expand the cells, we thawed a frozen vial of the cells, plated the cells in 60-cm2 culture dishes, and incubated them for 4 days in a recovery plate. These cells (passage 1) were used for further analyses.27,28,41 Six donors were excluded because it was impossible to gain a sufficient amount of passage 0 cells (enthesis: 4 cases; tendon: 3 cases. The total does not add up because of overlapping) (Figure 1).

We finally investigated 14 men and 5 women (age [mean ± standard deviation], 64.0 ± 9.1 years) who had full-thickness rotator cuff tears (Figure 1). The average size of the rotator cuff tear was 8.6 ± 7.7 cm2. According to the Goutallier classification,19 10 of the 19 tears were class 1, and 9 were class 2. The specimens from 3 donors were used for the histological studies including hematoxylin and eosin (Figure 2B) and toluidine blue staining (Figure 2C).

sec.title: In Vitro Expandability and Cell Viability Assay
sec.p: To examine the in vitro expandability of cells from each type of mesenchymal tissue, passage 1 cells were replated at 50 cells/cm2 in 150-cm2 culture dishes every 14 days until their expansion potential was lost.41 To determine the live/dead status of cells in each passage, the cells were stained with use of LIVE/DEAD Viability/Cytotoxicity Kit for mammalian cells (Invitrogen). In addition, a colorimetric assay for cell viability was conducted by plating passage 4 cells at 5000 cells in a 24-well multidish (Nalge Nunc International) and culturing them with 500 μL of complete medium for 7 days. After incubation of the cells, 50 μL of Cell Counting Kit-8 (highly water-soluble tetrazolium salt, WST-8, Dojindo, Kumamoto, Japan) was added to each well, and the dish was incubated for an additional 1 hour. Cells were counted by using a spectrophotometer multiplate reader at 450 nm (SH1000, Corona Electric, Ibaraki, Japan), and cell viability was evaluated. Cell viability was expressed as a percentage based on the viable cell count of the synovium (100%).

sec.title: Estimation of the Yield Obtained
sec.p: To clarify which tissue was most sufficient to obtain the cells for clinical application, we estimated the number of live passage 0 cells gained from the whole volume of each tissue and identified as the yield obtained.

sec.title: Adipogenesis in a Colony-Forming Assay
sec.p: For adipogenesis experiments, 100 passage 1 cells were plated in 60-cm2 dishes and cultured in complete medium for 14 days. The cells were then switched to adipogenic medium, which consisted of complete medium supplemented with 10−7 M dexamethasone (Sigma-Aldrich), 0.5 mM isobutyl-1-methylxanthine (Sigma-Aldrich), and 50 μM indomethacin (Wako), for an additional 21 days. The adipogenic culture was fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde and stained with fresh Oil Red O (Sigma-Aldrich) solution, and the number of Oil Red O–positive colonies was counted. Colonies less than 2 mm in diameter and those that stained faintly were ignored. The same adipogenic cultures were subsequently stained with crystal violet, and total cell colonies were counted.46

sec.title: Osteogenesis in a Colony-Forming Assay
sec.p: For osteogenesis studies, 100 passage 1 cells were plated in 60-cm2 dishes and cultured for 14 days. The cells were then switched to a calcification medium consisting of complete medium supplemented with 10−9 M dexamethasone, 20 mM β-glycerol phosphate (Wako), and 50 μg/mL ascorbate-2-phosphate for an additional 21 days. The osteogenic culture was fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde. Thereafter, mineralized bone nodule formation was assessed by double labeling for mineral (von Kossa stain) and alkaline phosphatase (ALP),2,37 and positive colonies were counted. The same osteogenic cultures were subsequently stained with crystal violet, and the total cell colonies were counted. Colonies that were <2 mm in diameter and those that appeared yellowish were ignored.40

sec.title: In Vitro Chondrogenesis Using a Pellet Culture Assay
sec.p: For chondrogenesis studies, 250,000 passage 2 cells were placed in a 15-mL polypropylene tube (Becton Dickinson) and centrifuged at 450g for 10 minutes. The pellet was cultured in chondrogenesis medium (high-glucose Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium [Invitrogen] supplemented with 500 ng/mL BMP-2, 10 ng/mL TGF-β3 [R&D Systems, Minneapolis, Minnesota], 10−7 M dexamethasone [Sigma-Aldrich], 50 μg/mL ascorbate-2-phosphate, 40 μg/mL proline, 100 μg/mL pyruvate, and 50 mg/mL ITS+Premix [Becton Dickinson]). The medium was replaced every 3 to 4 days for 21 days. For microscopy, the pellets were embedded in paraffin, cut into 4-μm sections, and stained with toluidine blue.44,47

sec.title: Immunohistochemistry
sec.p: Four-micrometer-thick sections obtained from the tissue specimens were deparaffinized and treated with 20 μg/mL proteinase K (DakoCytomation, Copenhagen, Denmark) for 10 minutes at room temperature. After sections were washed with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), they were placed in methanol containing 0.3% H2O2 for 20 minutes to block endogenous peroxidase. The sections were washed again with PBS and treated with blocking reagent (Protein Block Serum-Free, DakoCytomation) at room temperature. Sections were incubated with primary anti-human collagen II antibody (ab34712, Abcam, Cambridge, United Kingdom) for 30 minutes and then with anti-human anti-collagen type X antibody (C7974, Sigma-Aldrich) for 12 hours at 4°C. The sections were rinsed again with PBS repeatedly and then incubated with immune peroxidase polymer secondary antibody (Histofine, Nichirei Biosciences, Tokyo, Japan) for 30 minutes. Antibodies were visualized by treating the sections with diaminobenzidine tetrahydrochloride (ChemMate DAB+ Chromogen, DakoCytomation) for 5 minutes. To assess the specificity of the collagen type X antibody, human chondrosarcoma underwent the same treatment as the sections and served as the positive control. Specificity of the immunoreactivities was confirmed by replacing the primary antibodies with normal rabbit serum.

sec.title: Epitope Profile
sec.p: One million passage 2 cells were resuspended in 200 μL of PBS containing a fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC)– or phycoerythrin (PE)-coupled antibody. The FITC- or PE-coupled antibodies against CD34, CD44, CD45, CD90, CD147, and CD271 were from BD Biosciences (San Diego, California); CD117 was from eBioscience (San Diego, California); and CD105 and CD166 were from Ancell (Bayport, Minnesota). Vascular endothelial growth factor receptor 2 (VEGFR2) was from R&D Systems. After incubation for 30 minutes at 4°C, the cells were washed with PBS and then resuspended in 350 μL of PBS for analysis. As an isotype control, FITC- or PE-coupled nonspecific mouse IgG (BD Biosciences) was substituted for the primary antibody. Cell fluorescence was evaluated by flow cytometry using an EPICS XL instrument (Coulter Co, Tokyo, Japan), and data were analyzed using a MultiCycle AV analysis program (Phoenix Flow System Inc, San Diego, California).43,48 Positive expression was defined as fluorescence more than 99% greater than that of the corresponding isotype-matched control antibodies.

sec.title: DNA Microarray Analysis
sec.p: Total RNA was prepared from passage 0 cells using RNeasy Plus kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany); 500 ng of total RNA was used to synthesize double-stranded cDNA (RT2 First Strand Kit, SABiosciences, Frederick, Maryland). Human stem cells from the RT2 Profiler PCR Array System (PAHS-405A, SABiosciences) containing 89 stem cell–specific and differentiation genes were used. The fluorescence intensity of each probe was quantified by using an iCycler apparatus (Bio-Rad Laboratories Inc, Hercules, California) associated with the iCycler Optical System Interface software (version 3.1, Bio-Rad Laboratories). Further data analysis was performed with RT2 Profiler web-based PCR Array Data Analysis (SABiosciences).43,48

sec.title: Quantitative Real-Time Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)
sec.p: Cells that entered adipogenesis or osteogenesis were trypsinized, and total RNA was obtained with use of the RNeasy Mini Plus kit (Qiagen) according to the manufacturer’s protocol. The chondrogenic pellet was homogenized using BioMasher (Nippi, Tokyo, Japan), and total RNA was prepared from a single pellet using RNeasy Micro Plus kit (Qiagen). Total RNA was reverse-transcribed in a 20-μL reaction by use of High Capacity RNA-to-cDNA Master Mix (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, California) according to the manufacturer’s recommendations. To determine mRNA expression levels in each sample, cDNA was assayed by use of 9 TaqMan probes: for adipogenesis, adipsin (complement factor D; Hs00157263_m1), peroxisome proliferator–activated receptor γ (PPARG; Hs0111 5513_m1), and lipoprotein lipase (LPL; Hs00173425_m1); for calcification, collagen type I α 1 (COL1A1; Hs001 64004_m1), alkaline phosphatase placental type (ALPP; Hs03046558_s1), and Runt-related transcription factor 2 (RUNX2; Hs00231692_m1); and for chondrogenesis, collagen type II α 1 (COL2A1; Hs00264051_m1), collagen type X α 1 (COL10A1; Hs00166657_m1), and sex determining region Y–box 9 (SOX9; Hs00165814_m1) probes (Applied Biosystems) were used. To detect an adequate endogenous control gene, we performed a gene expression assay by use of TaqMan Array Human Endogenous Control (Applied Biosystems), and β-actin (ACTB; Hs99999903_m1) was identified as a relevant control for normalization of gene expression (data not shown). StepOnePlus Real-Time PCR System was used for the quantification, and analysis was performed using StepOnePlus software (version 2.0, Applied Biosystems).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: To assess the difference in isolation status as well as the character of cells from 4 sources of shoulder tissue, we used the Kruskal-Wallis rank analysis of variance. We used the Steel-Dwass test to make pairwise comparisons between groups. A value of P < .05 was considered significant.

sec.title: Histological Study
sec.p: Histological study revealed that the synovium as well as subacromial bursa consisted of several layers of synovial cells and subsynovial tissue and that the supraspinatus tendon included collagen fiber covered by synovial cells (Figure 2B). The enthesis consisted of a smaller number of cells compared with the other 3 tissues. The toluidine blue staining was positive at the matrix of the enthesis, while the others were negative (Figure 2B and 2C).

sec.title: Tissue Collection and Cell Isolation
sec.p: Sample weight obtained and nucleated cell number per milligram of a sample are shown in Table 1. The sample weight of the subacromial bursa was significantly higher than those of the synovium and enthesis (P < .05, Kruskal-Wallis test, post hoc Steel-Dwass test). The nucleated cell number per milligram of the subacromial bursa was the highest among 4 tissues; however, there were no significant differences among the other 3 tissues.

To gain a maximum number of colonies per amount of nucleated cells, we examined the effect of plating density on nucleated cells from each type of mesenchymal tissue from the 16 donors. For example, from subacromial bursa tissue, large single cell–derived colonies occurred when nucleated cells were plated at 103 or 104 cells/60-cm2 dish. If nucleated cells were plated at 105 cells/60-cm2 dish, the colonies were smaller or became indistinct (Figure 2D) possibly because of contact inhibition. These data indicate that the optimal initial cell density for subacromial bursa tissue is 104 cells/60-cm2 dish. The optimal initial cell density was 104/60-cm2 dish for all 4 mesenchymal tissues. Colony number per nucleated cell number was highest for the subacromial bursa, and cell number per colony was highest for the synovium (not significant) (Table 1). The cell structure at 14 days is shown in Figure 2E. The cells from 4 tissues seemed to be similar and to be fibroblastic cell types.

sec.title: In Vitro Expandability and Cell Viability Assay
sec.p: To investigate the in vitro expandability of each mesenchymal tissue–derived cell, we replated the cells at 50 cells/cm2 every 14 days. Expandability was lost at passage 7 for supraspinatus tendon– and enthesis-derived cells and at passage 8 for synovium-derived cells. The expandability of the subacromial bursa cells was retained even at passage 10 (Figure 3A).

caption.p: Proliferation potential and cell viability assay of mesenchymal tissue–derived cells. (A) Passage 1 cells from each type of mesenchymal tissue were plated at 50 cells/cm2 on 150-cm2 dishes. Thereafter, the cells were replated at 50 cells/cm2 every 14 days until their expansion potential was lost. (B) LIVE/DEAD Viability/Cytotoxicity Kit assay. At passage 0, green fluorescence was observed in all cells derived from each tissue, confirming that these cells were alive. Half of passage 4 cells derived from the supraspinatus tendon and enthesis were dead, but those from the synovium and subacromial bursa were still alive. Bar = 100 μm. (C) Cell Counting Kit-8 assay for passage 4 cells. Viability of cells derived from the synovium and subacromial bursa was equal, in addition to being superior to that of supraspinatus tendon and enthesis cells. Cells from 3 donors were examined, and similar results were obtained. Cells from 1 representative donor are shown.

sec.p: By use of the LIVE/DEAD Viability/Cytotoxicity Kit, we determined that all passage 0 cells derived from each tissue were alive. At passage 4, almost all cells derived from the synovium and subacromial bursa were still alive. In contrast, about half of the tendon- and enthesis-derived cells were dead (Figure 3B).

According to the Cell Count Kit-8 assay, cell viability of synovium- and subacromial bursa–derived cells was higher than that of tendon- and enthesis-derived cells (P < .05, Kruskal-Wallis test) (Figure 3C).

sec.title: Yield Obtained
sec.p: We estimated a live passage 0 cell number per milligram of tissue and the yield obtained (16 donors) (Table 1). The live passage 0 cell number per tissue of the synovium, subacromial bursa, supraspinatus tendon, and enthesis was 11.1 ± 19.7, 9.0 ± 18.1, 6.9 ±12.4, and 1.9 ± 2.7, respectively (×105 cells/mg; P = .16, Kruskal-Wallis test). Similarly, the yield obtained was 4.5 ± 7.7, 9.3 ± 15.3, 3.7 ± 6.4, and 1.1 ± 1.9, respectively (×107 cells; P = .02, Kruskal-Wallis test). The yield obtained of the subacromial bursa was significantly higher than the enthesis (P < .05, Steel-Dwass test) (Table 1).

sec.title: Adipogenesis
sec.p: To define the adipogenic potential of cells derived from the synovium, subacromial bursa, supraspinatus tendon, and enthesis, we measured adipogenesis in a colony-forming assay (6 donors). All samples generated colonies of adipocytes, which stained with Oil Red O (Figure 4A). The adipocyte colonies were approximately the same size; however, the number of Oil Red O–positive colonies varied. The number of Oil Red O–positive colonies was significantly higher in synovium- and subacromial bursa–derived cells than in supraspinatus tendon– and enthesis-derived cells (P < .0001, Kruskal-Wallis test; P < .05, post hoc Steel-Dwass test) (Figure 4B). In addition, real-time quantitative PCR analysis for adipogenic gene expression was performed (3 donors). As shown in Figure 4C, the expression of adipsin, PPARG, and LPL was highest for the synovium, followed by the subacromial bursa and the supraspinatus tendon, and much less for the enthesis (3 donors; P < .05, Kruskal-Wallis test). These results indicate that synovium- and subacromial bursa–derived cells have significantly greater adipogenic ability than do supraspinatus tendon– and enthesis-derived cells.

caption.p: Adipogenic potential of mesenchymal tissue–derived cells. One hundred passage 1 cells from each type of mesenchymal tissue were plated on 60-cm2 dishes and cultured for 14 days to form cell colonies. The cells were then cultured in adipogenic medium for an additional 21 days. (A) Colonies staining positively with Oil Red O and crystal violet by tissue source. (B) Proportion of Oil Red O–positive colonies in relation to the total number of colonies by tissue source. Values are the mean ± standard deviation in 6 donors. *The rate of Oil Red O–positive colonies from synovium- and subacromial bursa–derived cells was significantly higher than from tendon- and enthesis-derived cells (Kruskal-Wallis test, post hoc Steel-Dwass test, P < .0001). (C) Quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction. Data from 1 representative donor are shown. PPARG, peroxisome proliferator–activated receptor γ; LPL, lipoprotein lipase.

sec.title: Osteogenesis
sec.p: To evaluate the osteogenic potential of mesenchymal cells, osteogenesis was determined using a colony-forming assay (6 donors). Most subacromial bursa–derived cells generated colonies of osteogenic cells that stained with von Kossa/ALP double staining. In contrast, only some synovium-derived cells and few supraspinatus tendon– and enthesis-derived cells generated osteogenic colonies (Figure 5A). The number of von Kossa– and ALP-positive colonies was significantly higher in subacromial bursa–derived cells than in cells derived from the synovium, supraspinatus tendon, and enthesis (P < .0001, Kruskal-Wallis test; P < .05, post hoc Steel-Dwass test) (Figure 5B). According to a real-time PCR assay, the highest level of expression of COL1, ALP, and RUNX2 genes was observed with subacromial bursa–derived cells (3 donors; P < .05, Kruskal-Wallis test) (Figure 5C). These findings show that the osteogenic ability of subacromial bursa–derived cells is greater than that of synovium-, supraspinatus tendon–, and enthesis-derived cells.

caption.p: Osteogenic potential of mesenchymal tissue–derived cells. One hundred passage 1 cells from each type of mesenchymal tissue were plated on 60-cm2 dishes and cultured for 14 days to form cell colonies. The cells were then cultured in osteogenic medium for an additional 21 days. (A) Colonies staining positively with von Kossa and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) as well as crystal violet by tissue source. (B) Proportion of von Kossa– and ALP-positive colonies in relation to the total number of colonies by tissue source. Values are the mean ± standard deviation in 6 donors. *The rate of von Kossa– and ALP-positive colonies from subacromial bursa–derived cells was significantly higher than from synovium-, tendon-, and enthesis-derived cells (Kruskal-Wallis test, post hoc Steel-Dwass test, P < .0001). (C) Real-time polymerase chain reaction. Expression of COL1 (collagen type I), ALP, and RUNX2 (runt-related transcription factor 2) genes was the highest for the subacromial bursa (Kruskal-Wallis test, P < .05).

sec.title: Chondrogenesis
sec.p: To assess the chondrogenic potential of the cells derived from the mesenchymal tissues, we performed an in vitro chondrogenesis study using a pellet culture system (3 donors).47 Most of the pellets from each tissue were >0.5 mm in diameter. The enthesis pellets had a toluidine blue–stained cartilage matrix (Figure 6A). The amount of type X collagen was not confirmed by immunohistochemical analysis in every pellet from each tissue (data not shown); nonetheless, immunoreactivity for type II collagen was detected in enthesis-derived pellets but not in the other 3 tissues (Figure 6A). The real-time PCR study demonstrated expression of Col2A1 and Col10A1, especially for the enthesis, but SOX9 expression in subacromial bursa tissue was highest among the markers of chondrogenic differentiation (Figure 6B). These results revealed that enthesis-derived cells have greater chondrogenic potential compared with the other 3 tissues.

caption.p: Chondrogenic potential of mesenchymal tissue–derived cells. Passage 2 cells from each type of mesenchymal tissue were pelleted and incubated for 21 days for the study of in vitro cartilage formation. (A) Histological appearance with toluidine blue staining and immunohistochemical detection of type II collagen by tissue source. Bar = 200 μm. (B) Quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction. Data from 1 representative donor are shown. COL2a1, collagen type II α 1 ; COL10a1, collagen type X α 1; SOX9, sex determining region Y-box 9.

sec.title: Epitope Profile
sec.p: The rate of positivity for CD45 (hematopoietic cell marker), CD31 (endothelial cell marker), CD117 (C-kit, stem cell factor receptor), CD34 (hematopoietic progenitor cell antigen), VEGFR-2 (Flk-1), and NGFR9,31,40,41 was <2% in cells derived from the synovium, subacromial bursa, supraspinatus tendon, and enthesis. The rate of positivity for CD44 (hyaluronan receptor)35 and CD90 (Thy1)25 was 70% to 95% in all 4 populations. In contrast, the rate of positivity for CD105 (SH-2),3,35 CD147 (neuregulin),9 and CD166 (ALCAM, SB10)1 varied between the 4 populations. Positivity for CD105 and CD147 in cells from the subacromial bursa was 12.8% and 75.8%, respectively; in enthesis-derived cells, positivity was 0.1% and 27.0%, respectively. Similarly, the rates of positivity for CD166 in the synovium and the subacromial bursa were 9.9% and 13.4%, respectively; in supraspinatus tendon– and enthesis-derived cells, they were 1.3% and 4.3%, respectively (see Appendix 1, available in the online version of this article at http://ajs.sagepub.com/supplemental/).

sec.title: Microarray
sec.p: The RNA was prepared from each population of cells derived from a common donor at passage 0. Of 89 genes, we identified 7 whose maximum or minimum value was significantly different (P < .05) among the various mesenchymal tissues: BMP2, CXCL2, GJB2, S100B, IGF1, NCAM1, and JAG1 (see Appendix 2A, available online). We confirmed significantly higher expression of BMP2, CXCL2, GJB2, and S100B in the synovium compared with the other 3 mesenchymal tissues. On the other hand, the expression of IGF1 in the subacromial bursa was significantly higher than in the other 3 tissues. In addition, the expression of NCAM1 in the subacromial bursa and supraspinatus tendon was greater than in the synovium. Moreover, we identified higher expression of JAG1 in the subacromial bursa compared with the enthesis (see Appendix 2B, available online).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study has 8 major findings, as follows:

list-item.p: The colony number per nucleated cell number was highest for the subacromial bursa, and the number of cells per colony was highest in the synovium.
The yield obtained from the subacromial bursa was significantly higher than that obtained from the enthesis.
The proliferative ability of the subacromial bursa was retained even at passage 10.
The viability of synovium- and subacromial bursa–derived cells was significantly higher than that of supraspinatus tendon– and enthesis-derived cells.
Synovium- and subacromial bursa–derived cells had significantly greater adipogenic ability than did cells derived from the supraspinatus tendon or enthesis.
The osteogenic ability of subacromial bursa–derived cells was significantly greater than that of cells derived from the synovium, supraspinatus tendon, or enthesis.
Enthesis-derived cells had greater chondrogenic potential than did cells from the synovium, subacromial bursa, or supraspinatus tendon.
Flow cytometric analysis revealed that surface proteins of the passage 2 cells were characteristic of MSCs.
In addition, a microarray study demonstrated that the passage 0 cells expressed mRNA of MSCs.

sec.p: In this study, we used patient-matched samples for comparisons because MSCs from different patients have different properties.33,41 These 4 tissues were simultaneously digested for 2 hours to control for collagenase cytotoxicity.43 Also, the nucleated cells were plated at a density that precluded interaction between cell colonies, while permitting expansion to occur at a maximum rate.9,11,36,45 Furthermore, cells were compared at the same passage because the differentiation potential decreases after every passage.11,44 Our findings were congruent with these studies.

A previous synovial MSC study revealed that the expansion potential of MSCs derived from the knee synovium is retained at later passages.41 Similarly, our results showed that the expansion potential of cells derived from the subacromial bursa is retained at later passages than that of cells from the synovium, supraspinatus tendon, or enthesis. The MSCs derived from the subacromial bursa retained their proliferative ability even after passage 10, demonstrating that they have greater expandability than cells from the synovium, supraspinatus tendon, or enthesis.

With respect to differentiation, adipogenic potential was greater for cells derived from the subacromial bursa and synovium than for those from the supraspinatus tendon and enthesis. In addition, the cells derived from the subacromial bursa had significantly greater osteogenic potential than those from the other 3 mesenchymal tissues. Chondrogenic potential was greater in enthesis-derived cells than those from the synovium, subacromial bursa, or supraspinatus tendon. We determined that the differentiation potential of shoulder tissue–derived cells is dissimilar among the 4 tissues studied.

Microarray study yielded further information about differences between the 4 cell sources. IGF1 is known to be one of the most potent natural activators of the AKT signal pathway, which can promote growth factor–mediated cell proliferation, both directly and indirectly,15 and bone formation.51 The higher expression of IGF1 may link the greater proliferation ability and the osteogenic potential of subacromial bursa–derived cells.

Regarding surface markers, Sakaguchi et al41 and Segawa et al43 demonstrated that a population of cells derived from a human synovium and bone marrow was negative for CD34 and CD45 and positive for CD90, CD105, CD166, and CD44. Bi et al6 also showed that a population of cells derived from a human hamstring tendon was negative for CD34 and CD45 and positive for CD90 and CD44. On the other hand, a population of circulating osteoblast lineage human cells was positive for CD34.14 In our study, each population of cells was negative for CD34, CD45, CD31, CD117, NGFR, and VEGFR2 and positive for CD90, CD105, CD166, CD147, and CD44, confirming that the cells derived from the synovium, subacromial bursa, supraspinatus tendon, and enthesis had characteristics of MSCs and differed from circulating cells.

According to the International Society for Cellular Therapy position statement, the minimal criteria to define MSCs are as follows: (1) adherence to plastic, (2) specific surface antigen expression, and (3) multipotent differentiation potential.12 The cells derived from shoulder tissues seem to meet these criteria. It seems that these cells must be identified as MSCs.

Bi et al6 showed that cells derived from a human hamstring tendon are multipotent and distinct from bone marrow stromal cells. Additionally, Sakaguchi et al41 demonstrated that MSCs derived from the human synovium of the anterior cruciate ligament in an injured knee joint had greater potential for self-renewal and differentiation than those derived from bone marrow, periosteum, adipose tissue, or muscle. Results of our study indicate that the cells derived from the subacromial bursa and synovium have greater expansion and differentiation potential than those from the supraspinatus tendon. In a histopathological study, degenerative changes, including thinning and disorientation of collagen fibers, and myxoid and hyaline degeneration were observed in the margin of a torn supraspinatus tendon.22 We conclude that the degenerative change in the injured tendon is attributable to its poor MSC properties, which indicates that it is not a good source of MSCs.

As far as we are concerned, the present study is the first to show that cells derived from the enthesis are inferior to those derived from the subacromial bursa and synovium in terms of expandability, adipogenic potential, and osteogenic potential. Enthesis injuries such as lateral epicondylitis and Achilles tendinopathy are intractable disorders,8,38 which is consistent with our demonstration that enthesis cells are less capable of proliferation. In contrast, cells from the enthesis had greater chondrogenic potential than did the other 3 tissues. The rotator cuff insertion for the humerus has a fibrocartilage column5; however, rotator cuff repair surgery leads to direct attachment of the tendon to bone.18,34 As Nourissat et al34 reported, we believe that tendon-bone healing reconstructing the original enthesis must excel so that there is direct contact of the tendon to bone. Thus, we consider that the chondrogenic potential of MSCs is an important issue for tendon-bone healing. From this aspect, the enthesis seems to be a good candidate for the clinical application of rotator cuff repair surgery. To be practical for regenerative therapy, a cell source must be easy to harvest, and it must be possible to efficiently obtain nucleated cells after digestion.16 In the present study, the subacromial bursa was the easiest tissue to harvest via arthroscopic surgery, and we were able to obtain a larger sample from the subacromial bursa than from the other 3 tissues. On the other hand, as shown in Figure 1, we were unable to harvest a sufficient amount of tissue or to gain nucleated cells from the supraspinatus tendon or the enthesis on the greater tuberosity. We excluded 12 cases of insufficient harvest or culture from the supraspinatus tendon and similarly excluded 11 cases from the enthesis. There was a significantly higher rate of failure in collecting MSCs compared with the subacromial bursa (P < .001, Fisher exact test). In addition, after digestion with collagenase, the number of nucleated cells per milligram of tissue was much higher for the subacromial bursa than for other tissues. Further, the yield obtained from the subacromial bursa was the highest among these 4 tissues. These results demonstrate that the subacromial bursa is the superior source of MSCs. However, the chondrogenic potential in subacromial bursa cells was lower than that in enthesis cells. Further studies are warranted to increase the chondrogenic potential of the subacromial bursa to meet the cell source for the enthesis.

The remodeling process of rotator cuff tears remains unknown. It is controversial whether the subacromial bursa should be preserved when an operation for rotator cuff repair is performed. Uhthoff and Sarkar50 examined rotator cuff tear specimens and maintained that the main source of the reparative tissue was the wall of the subacromial bursa. Using a rabbit rotator cuff tear model, Hirose et al23 showed that spontaneous healing of the rotator cuff occurs from the subacromial bursal side rather than the articular side. In addition, our present study demonstrates the greater expandability and multipotency of cells derived from the subacromial bursa. This evidence supports the subacromial bursa playing a very important role in rotator cuff healing. Thus, studies in animal models with rotator cuff tears are clearly necessary to evaluate the biological effect of subacromial bursa–derived cells.

In an attempt to augment tendon-bone healing in a rat rotator cuff repair model, Gulotta et al20 used bone marrow stromal cells but found they were not effective for healing. However, they later succeeded in demonstrating that adenoviral membrane type 1 matrix metalloproteinase (MT1-MMP)–transduced bone marrow stromal cells can augment rotator cuff healing.21 Mazzocca et al30 performed arthroscopic rotator cuff repair using rapidly isolated bone marrow stromal cells, but no clinical improvement resulted. Recent studies demonstrated that circulating cells in peripheral blood have an osteogenic14 and MSC10 potential. The origin of these circulating cells is not known.13 In their cell culture study, Sakaguchi et al41 showed that the synovium was superior as a cell source compared with bone marrow. To our knowledge, there has been no comparison of mesenchymal tissue–derived cells with circulating cells in peripheral blood. At present, synovial tissue appears to be a promising cell source for regenerative therapy.16 The present study indicates that the subacromial bursa is an excellent source of MSCs in vitro. Further studies are necessary to clarify the underlying mechanisms of biological augmentation for bone-tendon healing in vivo.

Limitations of the present study are as follows. First, this is an in vitro study, and we cannot describe the potential of these MSCs in vivo. Second, patients were older, and no adolescents or younger people were enrolled. Third, the profiles as well as the history of the patients were different in each case. Another limitation is that we did not compare the mesenchymal tissues to bone marrow or peripheral blood.

In conclusion, we have demonstrated that human shoulder mesenchymal tissues, especially in the subacromial bursa, have mesenchymal properties. The subacromial bursa appears to be a good candidate for MSCs. Further animal studies are necessary to clarify the effectiveness of these cells in biological augmentation of rotator cuff repair surgery.

ack.p: The authors thank Nao Terada and Minako Nimura for management of the laboratory; Yuki Shimizu for expert help with fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS) analysis; Koshiro Sonomoto for special help with reverse transcription PCR; and Hidehiko Matsumoto, Akihisa Hatakeyama, Satoru Ohkuma, Kazuta Yamashita, and Michiharu Hara for continuous help with the collection of tissues during arthroscopic surgery.
